label.text: Spacecraft
The International Space Station (ISS) is a joint project of space agencies from five different countries.
The ISS obtains electricity from eight large arrays of solar panels.
Electrical energy is measured in units of power called watts. The ISS panels have a combined output of nearly 100,000 watts.
A trip from Earth to Mars currently takes more than 6 months.
A spacecraft transporting humans to Mars could consume electricity equal to that generated by the solar panels on the ISS.
Scientists are considering obtaining energy from a nuclear reactor for a piloted trip to Mars.
Large amounts of electricity are required for a piloted spacecraft trip.
Are each of the functions in the table below likely to require electricity during the trip?
Select ‘Yes’ or ‘No’ for each function.
maintaining a constant cabin temperature
operation of electronic instruments
communication with Earth
humans opening food packets
consumption of rocket fuel
The table contains true statements about the use of solar panels and of a nuclear reactor for a piloted trip to Mars.
Which of these statements are reasons for using a nuclear reactor instead of solar panels for a piloted trip to Mars?
Select ‘Yes’ or ‘No’ for each statement.
Solar panels work less efficiently as light intensity decreases with increasing distance from the Sun.
Radiation emitted from the nuclear reactor could be a health hazard for the astronauts.
A nuclear reactor cannot be repaired in space.
Solar panels are large and therefore more likely to be hit by space debris than a nuclear reactor.
A nuclear reactor can produce very large amounts of energy.
